heading: redmond to intuit: stop whining
subheading: responding to allegations that microsoft has a chokehold on the pc desktop, an attorney says porno sites don't have real estate there, either. declan mccullagh reports from washington.
author: declan mccullagh
text: washington -- as the microsoft antitrust trial resumed monday following the holiday recess, the software giant accused intuit's chief executive of joining forces with the government instead of competing fairly in the market. intuit ceo william harris seems to want a "national operating system commission" that would regulate the computer industry, a microsoft attorney suggested during cross-examination."i'm not proposing any such thing," replied harris, whose company's quicken personal-finance software competes with microsoft money. harris has asked the court to "separate" microsoft's operating-system business from its browser and application-software product line.a microsoft attorney took an unusual tack to counter harris' claim that microsoft has "substantial power to direct users" to sites that appear on the windows desktop."isn't it true that one of the most popular uses of the world wide web is to access pornography?" asked john warden.titillating images represent a "very significant" use of the web, harris admitted."no pornographic web site has a message, icon, or logo on the windows desktop," warden replied. he suggested that many sites become popular through search engines and by word of mouth, not as a result of microsoft's control over the windows desktop.warden said that contrary to harris' assertions, microsoft has no monopoly when placing icons on the desktop. computer makers and customers can add their own. "that's the same monopoly that time magazine has over its cover," warden said."i believe there's a distinction between the two," harris replied. "the distinction is that the operating system for most anyone who wants to compete is an essential service."during cross-examination on monday, two different views of the software industry battled for supremacy: a laissez-faire approach, where government's role is limited, and one that demands increased government involvement.
